newsitem.title: USA: U.S. jobless claims unchanged in latest week.
newsitem.headline: U.S. jobless claims unchanged in latest week.

text.p: U.S. Labor Department report of initial state jobless benefit claims, seasonally adjusted.
Week Ended Initial Claims 4-Week Avg. Continued Claims
R-Revised, Sept 14 Continued Claims from 2,499,000 and Sept 7 Continued Claims from 2,408,000.
Wall Street economists had forecast initial claims of 341,000 in the September 28 week.
The closely followed four-week moving average of claims inched up for the seventh consecutive week, the report showed.
Labor said four states reported decreases in initial claims exceeding 1,000 on an unadjusted basis in the week ended September 21, the latest period for which the data are available.
They were North Carolina, with 1,990 fewer claims; New York, with 1,886; Illinois, with 1,697; and Tennessee, with 1,075.
North Carolina cited fewer layoffs in the construction and textile industries. Illinois had fewer layoffs in the trade and service industries, and manufacturing.
Tennessee had fewer layoffs in textile, apparel, lumber, leather goods, electronic and transportation equipment, and service industries. New York had no comment.
Labor said Michigan and Puerto Rico reported increases in initial claims exceeding 1,000, unadjusted, in the September 21 week.
Michigan, with 1,310 additional claims cited layoffs in the automobile industry, while Puerto Rico, with 8,638 more filings, attributed the rise to the impact of Hurricane Hortense.
